Key Arguments: No individual or group can accurately represent the truth, making enforcement of the bill problematic.
The legislation could empower individuals who believe they are correct, even if they are wrong.
The bill could hinder the process of peer review and the correction of 'false truths'.
Historical examples like smoking and asbestos are cited as scenarios where accepted truths were later proven false.
Main Themes: Truth and Accuracy: Concerns about the ability to define and enforce truth.
Power and Authority: Worries about the concentration of power in determining truth.
Historical Precedents: Reference to past accepted truths that were later debunked.
Notable Quotes: No living person or body of people know truth and can accurately represent truth to then enforce this bill.
This will damage people and provide power to people that think they are correct even when they may be wrong.
Opposing false truths would get massive fines or gaol.
